[i]Mr. Pung Yung, coming at you with another review.[/i]

This might be the most beautiful game I've ever played.

Is it beautiful because it has excellent gameplay mechanics? [b]Not really.[/b]

Is it beautiful because it has an incredible art style? [b]Not necessarily.[/b]

Is it beautiful because its story touched me to my core? [b]It didn't, actually.[/b]

No, I think this game is beautiful because every single one of its elements come together to create one cohesive and unique experience. 

The world the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games take place in, The Zone, has been around for a long time, but for the first time I can see why it is that, despite its hazards and dangers, the games' characters travel here willingly. Mutants will try to rip you apart. Different factions will try to use you or just outright kill you, and the dangerous anomalies litter the environment. And yet, the quiet walks through the forests, the jokes and banter of the people huddling around the campfires, the glimmer of all the artifacts, and the sunrises welcoming a new day... They all reel you in.

If I had to talk more about the game itself, I really enjoy the slightly hardcore approach to it. The game is A LOT less punishing than its prequels, but you will still die easily if you are not careful. Coupled with the lovely gunplay, the combat is both tense, engaging, fun, and satisfying.

And seeing familiar locations and characters was really nice as well! 

I'll definitely do a 2nd playthrough at some point where I don't focus as much on finishing the story, but just focus on truly living as part of The Zone. 

[i]Mr. Pung Yung[/i]

I played 100 hours at launch, I enjoyed the game but it was missing a lot of core things that made stalker, well.. stalker.

1.7 update has drastically improved that, the interactions with NPCs now are for more akin to prior entries (still plenty of improvements possible - especially with "spawning" or coming online too close) but overall it has improved the core loop quite a bit.

Other components like economy I cannot yet speak on as my time into a new save is only 10-15 hours. But these things were easily adjusted with mods so it's not something I care too strongly about currently. Still plenty to improve, just less held back in modding.

Performance has technically improved but at least at 4k the improvement is negligble - and more a reduction in stutter rather than overall performance improvment. Apparently an engine upgrade is coming, not confirmed if it will be 1.8 but if performance is your concern I'd wait for that,

Performance is much better than I've expected considering the reviews. Did not crash once and I've only experienced two bugs, one of them was game-breaking but the game saves your progress quite regularly so it was not much of an issue. Overall, the game is smooth and I've not experienced any major performance issues with RTX 4070 SUPER and Ryzen 5 7600.

There are a few other minor issues though. Each one of them can be resolved by installing a mod so that's a plus. Keep in mind that installing mods will disable Steam achievements so I recommend installing a mod for that too.

1. Skif definitely needs more stamina and the parkour mechanics need to be improved. Jumping just once pretty much consumes half of your stamina and the other half you deplete in less than 5 seconds if you sprint. That amount of stamina is ridiculous given the entire game is about exploring and running is the only way to travel around the map. I would strongly recommend installing a mod that increases your stamina and fixes parkour mechanics.

2. Flashlight is way too dim. Every single time I turn my flashlight on I tell myself it's just not enough and turn on the NVG instead. Again, easily fixed by a mod but could've been there by default.

3. AI feels weird at times, especially human enemies at night - stealth doesn't really work half the time. Some of the human enemies have literal xray and aimbot and as a result some of the fights are very linear. This only applies for human enemies because I've quite enjoyed fighting the mutants - do not underestimate them, even on STALKER difficulty.

4. Weight limit. I was encumbered 90% of the time when playing without the mods even though I carried the most basic shit. I know I should not be carrying 5 assault rifles with me but at the same time do I really have to be encumbered all the time even though I only carry the essentials? Combine this with the laughable amount of stamina and the game is a very boring walking simulator - which was my experience for the first few hours. I did not give up though and I'm glad I didn't.

Now the positive things; Atmosphere is second to none. Exploring feels great, gunplay is fun and graphics are stunning, especially with Reshade. I also love the weather and the whole concept of Emission.

Good: 
1. Atmosphere. The feelies abound: terrifying, weird, awesome, austere, and intense. The scary parts had me saving every 5 seconds like a young gamer. Exploration actually feels like exploration. There are so many little things to find that are just cool. Also, getting to revisit old locations gives epic nostalgia feels.
2. Story. It's not convoluted nonsense (though, if you're here, you can indulge some fantasy). It touches on many elements of the setting, and takes you through most of the map w/o being linear. Depth of choice exists, and the factions are more defined than in the other games. Faction cutscenes are awesome, and there are both awesome moments and compelling twists. 
3. Graphics. Beautiful. A dark shelter at night, or running through a blowout is visually intense and captivating. There were multiple times I just soaked it in.
4. Balance between punishment and reward. I play on STALKER difficulty, so I'm hurting myself here, but your stupid choices are punishing enough that thinking is required (IMO should be more punishing, but that's me). But, rewards (read: gear) is plentiful.

The mid: 
1. English voice acting is flat. I was gonna do Ukrainian since it added to the environment for me, anyway, and it's not game-breaking, but it stood out as a weak spot.
2. Good gear gating is necessary, but seems cheap, and requires heavy investment in endgame stuff with limited game left to actually use it. Techs exist to upgrade your gear; endgame gear requires endgame techs, and upgrades really make a difference. IMO this makes sense so you don't just breeze through everything, but by the time you get endgame gear and open up endgame upgrades, it's the end of the game. You can also just run to the endgame techs at any time, so it seems cheaply implemented.
3. There's so much loot to the extent scarcity doesn't matter. Sure, I hump literally everything back and forth, so maybe this varies, but I never ran out of anything. I never used the high-end medkits, but have hundreds of them. The top-tier gun ammo is more limited, but is also easily findable. Another limitation/check on too fast progress that doesn't quite hit.
4. Story gaps, setting changes w/o explanation. I'm a big atmosphere sponge, so finding, for example, an entire outpost turned into zombies worth understanding. But there's nothing to find. There's also lots of talk about what the Zone should be, but it's not well detailed enough for me to care. This doesn't break the game, but lost chances for setting depth.
5. Gunplay. To explain, understand that Sniping at extreme distance is not really doable. Draw distance, though it's considerable, still limits long guns. Thus, there becomes two main categories to the guns: 1) fast-firing, low-damage, medium/short range (assault rifles, subbies) and 2) slow-firing, high-damage, long/short range (sniper rifles, shotguns). IMO this is reductive once weapons are fully upgraded, such that every gun starts to feel the same, short of effective range and rate of fire.
6. Limited/mixed survivalism. You gotta eat, you gotta sleep, but: not doing so really does nothing. Pet peeve, you don't, also, need to specifically hydrate. I also like the idea of embracing more nuanced wound healing (sorta the way Tarkov does it now). This ain't for everyone, but surivalism is a big mechanic and theme in these games; there should be more depth, at least as an option.

The bad:
1. Story-wise, the basic reason the main character is in the Zone is thin. Then, during the intro he gets really pissed about getting screwed over. Both of these are part of the mystery, and, in context, matters a lot, but the rest of the time I'm just thinking this guy is exceptionally pissed about his apartment getting blown up. Sure, you get answers and a shift to the real, intense narrative pretty early, but it's still laughable IMO.
2. Repairs. It's 10000% intended to be another gear gate, but your stuff gets fucked quickly, and are so expensive to repair it's just annoying, especially early/mid game. Endgame, you got so much and can access all the means of making money that it's less of an issue, but I put this in bad cause it's so frustrating.
3. NPC spawns, pathing, and artifact spawns are static. There's some variety in what spawns, but you run into basically the same stuff. This maybe works for mutant, you don't want to just randomly run into pseudo giants everywhere, but it gets stale. IMO the Zone should be way more empty and varied than it's been in any STALKER game, but this was a bigger component in this game than the others.

Bugs
There are bugs that should get fixed, and the game could benefit from optimization. The level of bitching about bugs compared to what actually exists is ridiculous, though. The game doesn't crash every 5 minutes, every hour, etc. The only two crashes I've had were related to outdated Nvidia drivers. And, my brothers in Christ, I might have a 5070, but everything else in my rig is 3+ years old. My game is stable at 80-100 fps on epic settings at 2k.

There are valid complaints, but the QA issues on launch, prioritizing release timelines, are not unique to STALKER or GSC. I see this game ~1 year on has not been abandoned as a good thing, compared with the endless other $60-$70 AAA games by much bigger studios being run like a pump-and-dump scheme. IMO, stop preordering games to avoid this shit, and, though I agree all studios should be better, don't misrepresent what the game actually is.

Finally getting round to playing this game through a year after the release as someone with no history in the Stalker franchise, first timing the game on veteran difficulty and what I will start by saying is, the game generally is enjoyable, and the world itself is interesting and fun to explore, since I wouldn't have finished it if it wasn't, however, there are some problems with the game. 

The performance as many others elude to, is rough, I messed around with the settings at the start and could never find myself consistently getting above 60fps (I have a 2080Ti and a pretty decent PC set up that handles other games with no problem), and so I had to make the decision to just accept I would be playing the game at roughly 30-40fps, which whilst not ideal, was still playable at least, with some areas like settlements dropping to 20-25fps (which was rough at times so I just made sure to get in and get out as quickly as possible). 

The story and the world itself isn't bad, and there are some really awesome looking environmental effects (emissions and tornadoes etc), the gun play and the overall feel of the game felt satisfying, most of the weapons were pretty cool and fun to use, and the customisation whilst limited, still existed at least. But I have to say towards the end of the main story line, it really just started to feel like a running simulator, designed to extend the "run time" of the game and story by making you just run ridiculous distances between locations with fast travel being a very limited option in the game. It started to feel more like a chore and tedious, rather than enjoyable, which it had been for the first 20-30 hours of the game. 

A few less game breaking but small annoyances I found in the game:

- Lack of distinction between the factions in the games out in the world, figuring out who is an ally or enemy is very challenging at times, and every now and then I would accidentally shoot an ally thinking they were an enemy and turn them against me. Every NPC just seems to be wearing the same outfit with maybe a tiny clothing/helmet difference which is hard to tell mid gun fight. 
- Stamina/weight management/economy, as far as I can tell, they made the economy a little better, but it's very easy to be overweight, and with the amount of running you are forced into doing, it felt like I was forever battling my stamina bar getting from location to location. 
- Lack of incentive for killing mutants, after a while, some of the mutants just become annoying to fight, and since they rarely drop anything, it felt like 70% of the time it was just more convenient to avoid or run past them and save ammo.
- Story decisions not really feeling overly impactful, outside of a few choices that ultimately lead you to 1 of 4 alternate endings, it didn't really feel like my conversational decisions held that much weight (not sure if this is by design or not)
- Loot and stashes eventually becoming pretty repetitive 
- Occasional game crashes or side quest bugs

I do think there is a heart of a really good game here, and as I mentioned, playing this as someone with no previous Stalker experience, the game for what it is, is fun and that's why I am giving the game a thumbs up, I still found enough enjoyment to make my way through the game without any major issues or soft locks. But generally it's a shame that the game is still in this type of state or has been treated this way even a year later, because I feel as though with some genuine care and attention, this game could be everything that it was promised to be. 

TLDR- The game is generally fun and enjoyable, but performance and FPS are a problem, as well as some game play elements that make things feel a little tedious at times. So you need to weigh up both sides of that coin to decide whether it's worth paying for.

Stalker 2 is a game I was very excited for. It was a game I was willing to give a lot of leeway, due to the issues with development and the circumstances around the development near the end. Unfortunately, It failed to meet even those low expectations. 

Now to describe the developers of this game as lazy, or lacking in passion, would be untrue. They are, you can tell they are. The issue I think is simply that Stalker 2...either became too big, or somewhere down the line things began going poorly or their skill was simply not up the task. I hope the final point to not be the case.

The early to mid game is fairly good. Its quite content rich. The issue of course, is anything after reaching SIRCCA. The amount of content available to the player drops substantially, and lets not forget the rather tedious boss fights. On top of that, beloved characters feel changed or outright wasted and no real reason is given, or at least not a satisfying one and this even extends to entire Factions. I mean at no point does Duty, Freedom, Mercs or anyone other than the new factions, and Monolith take part in the main plot. (woulda been cool to find some clear sky faction references through rare suits or something like that)

Then we have the fact that A-life was not there in launch, and only just now are we getting something that resembles the bones of A-life, while it lacks the muscle and sinew of what we expected. The various animals of the zone feel less natural than Shadow of Chernobyl for crying out loud (They don't drag bodies back to their "Dens" and who thought the Bloodsucker eating animation was a good idea? It in the name guys, come on) A game that is over 10 years old on a far, far smaller budget Human enemies are aimbots, quite simply. What made Human enemies in the old games fun to fight against is that they would flank you, they would sneak up on you. The AI does try to flank you, certainly, the key word being try. The areas where combat takes place in built up areas, typically don't have many flanking routes for the AI and this is despite the fact the areas are generally bigger than the old games. Meanwhile, in the rather bland open areas they simply walk towards you. If there's cover, they will use it now, which is certainly an improvement from launch, but if there's little cover they simply walk at you, not left or right, directly towards you, making headshots incredibly easy. Its certainly more A than I.

Then we have the map itself. Simply put, the Map is too big. Having to run 2 Kilometres to my next objective wouldn't be so bad, so long as I found something to do along the way, but there is very little. You may find some old locations, a stash or two if you have the right edition of the game but other than that, bugger all. Quite frankly I would have preferred that they did what the OG games did, but made the areas larger. This would have meant more detail, less strain on PC's and A-life likely wouldn't have taken this long to get the bare minimum working and felt more impactful.

I could go on for several more paragraphs, but won't. All in all, while I can appreciate the passion of the developers, I don't appreciate that the game we were promised, and the game we got, are 2 very, very different games. I wanted a Stalker game, I got...whatever this is. Perhaps in a few years, the game will be worthy of being a sequel to the 3 (Clear sky I judged you too harshly) previous games titled Stalker, but as it is right now, it isn't.

It's a shallow example of the Stalker series. The visuals are a blurry, grainy mess. There are interesting environments, scattered throughout but are then mostly devoid of anything to do or see. The vegetation is incredibly underwhelming compared to the previous games. There's a whole lot more of it, but its all spindly, short and half dead. In universe, the zone has been pumping and growing the environment and wildlife for decades now but it doesn't look or feel like it at all. Lost alpha (an old mod for Shadow of chernobyl) does a far better job of bringing this vision to life with a tiny group of fans. 
Where you use to come across camps of people that made it feel like the zone was lived in, now in this game most sites/buildings are empty unless related to an active mission. It took over a year for that to be sort of rectified and it still feels all wrong.
In odd contrast, the zone is swarming in all the spaces between locations, nonstop with random wandering groups and mutants that are constantly at war with each other. It's sometimes constant explosions and gunfire in the distance, for minutes as you travel between places. A lot of the time its with groups that you wouldn't imagine seeing in that part of the map. It makes it feel like there's a 100,000 or more Stalkers living there and its and active warzone.  Then most of the main hubs are oddly empty in comparison.  Just the bare minimum amount of people. At least in the old games the had limits with the technology and the engine. They don't have that excuse almost 15 years later. 15!!!!! Yet the old games still feel so much more refined, and complete.
There are definitely QOL improvements in the gameplay and otherwise but with features like the vaulting, it 's woefully inconsistent. Night vision was completely until very very recently (after the community complaining for a year), but the nights and environments are darker than ever and the flashlight somehow weaker. which is only worsened by the fact the enemies can spot you from a mile away, night or day, and also hit you from that distance with a sawed off double barrel with regular shells. And good luck spotting them flitting through the messy foliage. But don't worry they always know where you are and will always walk right up to it even if you moved around when out of sight. Also stealth just doesn't work unless you are using the default pistol or the glitchy knife execution mechanic they put in. I don't know why every gun has a suppressor option if only one consistently works.
Most of the game was an irritating mess when it first came out, and mods were the only way to get through it the first few months. Overhauls for AI, spawns, combat, weather, graphics/optimization, QOL, and so on. Everything had to be fixed, everything. And only in the last couple months has the game really started to reach a more complete state. (unfortunately an industry standard practice at this point so not an exclusive issue). Also a purely  political decision they made was to remove as much as they possibly could, relating to the soviet union. Symbols markings, etc. So in otherwords one of the core aspects of the aesthetic of the entire series. The developers must have forgot that the soviet union was a completely different entity from the modern day Russia. Yes Russia is a bad actor in todays global politics still, but the developers erased and censored that history from the series because they felt butt hurt. Its naive, immature and shortsighted. 
The story is rough. They clearly knew the lore but cherry picked and added too much new random stuff while completely sidelining nearly all pre-existing groups. Motivations and actions largely don't make sense. There were cool things they explored but in the end it felt like the zone was somehow cheapened and made less impressive. 

A personal gripe I have is with the main hubs and bases still being dirty, completely ramshackle environments. Some of these bases have been around for a decade and a half but nobody has removed the broken glass from the main walkways and bedrooms, or moved out old boards and crates or patched over the windows?? I don't expect them to have remodeled and renovated their spaces and thrown up a live laugh love sign, but even the biggest richest faction are living in pockmarked hovels with debris ridden floors. Nobody has a broom or knows how to lift stuff? Yet they have a bunch of custom welded structures and the resources to carry that out? It just little details but when everything else is lacking, things like this start to stick out far more. 
The last negative thing I have to say is that the Map and open world are a detriment, at least how they implemented it. The location of everything is changed and the landscapes massively altered. I believe they wanted to reflect the real world geography better, but why bother after 3 games that put a greater emphasis on the game design/progress for the layout. The paths characters took in the past games just don't make sense anymore. Also The locations from the old games, are often just there for nostalgia with little reason to stop there besides check for loot. which would normally be fine, since you can't just keep reusing the same exact locations endlessly, but again in a disappointing game like this it just makes you sad when you come across them. . 

The GOOD is that the developers do seem dedicated to trying to rectify the endless list of bugs/glitches/issues that plague the game at every turn and have been pretty consistent about updates. Some small bits of extra stuff (weapons, night vision, etc) have been added as well. The modding scene is decent but there isn't anything to crazy to write home about. But there's at least a mod to fix most issues and add some much needed features or changes. 
Though I criticized quite a bit, there are definitely cool moments/ideas, fun fights on occasion and cool areas to roam but in the end it was just a big fat meh.
